linkTarget.anchoringText: Over time, some of the water injecters and oil producers were converted to WAG injection. Most of the pool is pressure supported by fluid injection. Figure 1 shows the map for the field location and areas of the waterflood and CO2 EOR schemes. By the end of 2015, there were 751 wells, of which 304 were active.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Field Location and surface map of Midale

formatted-caption.caption-text: Field Location and surface map of Midale

linkTarget.anchoringText: The productive interval found at a depth of approximately 1,400m is the Midale Carbonate, which is overlain and underlain by impervious anhydrite beds. The 20m thick productive interval is subdivided into an upper dolomitic unit (Marly) and a lower limestone unit (Vuggy). Figure 2 shows the reservoir characteristics.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Midale Beds - Reservoir Characteristics

formatted-caption.caption-text: Midale Beds - Reservoir Characteristics

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Vuggy Intershoal facies primarily consist of lower porosity peloidal and bioclastic packstones. The Vuggy Shoal section contains high-permeability peloidal grainstones. Vuggy dominated performance is characterized by faster flood-front breakthrough, lower oil rates and higher watercuts. Naturally fractured systems are suspected in the NESW direction as presented in Figure 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Midale Beds — Natural Fractures System and Orientation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Midale Beds — Natural Fractures System and Orientation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 4 shows a schematic the placements of the pool wells, which are mainly perpendicular to the natural fracture orientation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Midale Beds – Natural Fractures and Wells Placements

formatted-caption.caption-text: Midale Beds – Natural Fractures and Wells Placements

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5 shows the production response from the beginning of the waterflood. In addition, one objective with the waterflood is to increase the average reservoir pressure. The initial pool pressure was 14,900 kPa, and the CO2 miscibility pressure is estimated between 14,000 and 16,000 kPa.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Midale Waterflood Area’s Production Response since beginning of WTR (Oil Rate (sm3/d), Water Cut(%), Water lnj Rate (sm3/d)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Midale Waterflood Area’s Production Response since beginning of WTR (Oil Rate (sm3/d), Water Cut(%), Water lnj Rate (sm3/d)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The EOR scheme currently consists of 25 CO2 injectors and 138 oil wells (active). The CO2 injected is a mixture of supply volumes plus the recycle/produced gas, which is composed of recycled CO2 and produced solution gas. CO2 injection is directed at the highest performing patterns. Figure 6 shows the production response associated with the CO2 injection. As with water, oil production and gas oil ratio (GOR) increased shortly after initiating CO2 injection.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Midale CO2 Area’s Production Response in the since beginning CO2 Injection (Oil Rate (sm3/d), Water Cut(%), Water lnj Rate (sm3/d)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Midale CO2 Area’s Production Response in the since beginning CO2 Injection (Oil Rate (sm3/d), Water Cut(%), Water lnj Rate (sm3/d)

linkTarget.anchoringText: These efforts are exhibiting success by reducing oil declines, sometimes even increasing oil production, while reducing costs associated with the amount of injection and associated costs. Figure 7 shows the Midale production history and response after implementing such practices, and it is believed that further improvements are possible by utilizing flow control technology.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Midale Production History and Production Response since the 2014 Integrated Approach

formatted-caption.caption-text: Midale Production History and Production Response since the 2014 Integrated Approach

linkTarget.anchoringText: For passive ICDs a crossflow nozzle (CFN), as shown in Figure 8, in its standard version with two opposing throats, was chosen over a standard nozzle (single throat) because it significantly reduces the velocity of the fluid exiting the nozzle during production, thereby reducing the risk of erosion-corrosion on surfaces directly downstream of the nozzle.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Standard Version of CrossFlow Nozzle

formatted-caption.caption-text: Standard Version of CrossFlow Nozzle

linkTarget.anchoringText: The AICV technology consists of a valve that is actuated by the pressure drop response of the fluid through a laminar and turbulent flow restrictor in series [1, 2, 3]; Figure 9 illustrates the principle. The main flow enters a conduit, A, at inlet (wellbore) pressure P1. A minor pilot flow, parallel to the main flow, is passing through the laminar flow element where a pressure drop occurs, and the pressure in chamber is reduced to P2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Combination of Laminar and Turbulent flow restrictors in series.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Combination of Laminar and Turbulent flow restrictors in series.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 shows drawings of the AICV in open and closed positions. The thin blue lines present the pilot flow path, the thickest blue arrows presents the inlet of the main flow to the valve, and the two horizontal arrows show the outlet of the main flow to the base pipe. The thin blue vertical arrow presents the outlet of the pilot flow.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Schematic of AICV in open and closed position(ACIV Open Position, ACIV Closed Position)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic of AICV in open and closed position(ACIV Open Position, ACIV Closed Position)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The force balance around the piston is controlling the piston position, as shown in Figure 11. The force, F1, on the upper part of the piston (p1·A1) is acting downwards and the force F2 below the piston (p2·A2) is acting upwards. Ffric is a friction force, which will work against the direction of fluid flow.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: The AICV piston areas and forces acting on them

formatted-caption.caption-text: The AICV piston areas and forces acting on them

linkTarget.anchoringText: The specification of flow rates are based on the reservoir and fluid properties. A prototype AICV was tested with relevant fluids’ properties, and Figure 12 shows the AICV performance curves for oil (1.2 and 2.7 cP), water and CO2. As can be seen from the figure, the prototype AICV will close for CO2 and water and keep open for oil. When open, the AICV behaves like a passive ICD with an equivalent flow restriction (orifice) area of about 20 mm^2 per valve (See Equation 1 above).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Performance curves for AICV for oil, water and gas

formatted-caption.caption-text: Performance curves for AICV for oil, water and gas

linkTarget.anchoringText: Premium port [4] is a unique downhole 3-position (2-port) full bore valve that can be either closed or opened to one of two ICD settings or ICD types, as dictated by the position of a short sleeve as shown in Figure 13 (A 2-position or 1-port version is also available). The sleeve, shown with ICD1 open, can be shifted to either the closed position or to ICD2 position using special shifting tools run on jointed pipe, coil tubing, or wireline tractor.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: 2-Port 3ICI with facsrite debris screen

formatted-caption.caption-text: 2-Port 3ICI with facsrite debris screen

linkTarget.anchoringText: The sleeve, as shown in Figure 14, is designed to minimize the risk of sticking over time, caused primarily by surface deposition which plagues conventional sliding sleeves. The sleeve length and stroke are very short. The metallurgy on sliding surfaces is specially treated to minimize surface deposition. Scrapers are installed to scrape deposition off of surfaces when shifted. A special seal technology (not o-rings) is used to achieve high pressure differential ratings in the closed position. The detent rings are used to adjust the amount of shifting force that is desired for surface readout.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Cross Section of 3ICI Sliding Sleeve

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross Section of 3ICI Sliding Sleeve

linkTarget.anchoringText: For this project the standard 3ICI valve had to be customized in order to accommodate the AICV, which is significantly larger than nozzle ICDs. The assembly had to be small enough on the OD to fit inside 5.5" casing (4.89" drift ID). And the sub had to be short because the zones with thin. Hence, two 3ICI valves were integrated into one sub to allow 4 different ICD types or settings, as shown in Figure 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: AICV and CFN Integrated to 3ICI Valve

formatted-caption.caption-text: AICV and CFN Integrated to 3ICI Valve

linkTarget.anchoringText: The 3ICI valves can be switched to different positions by means of a unique shifting tool which is run on coiled tubing, conventional tubing or drill string [4]. Figure 16 shows the standard tool, but for this project a custom tool was designed because of the inside diamater required. Any valve can be controlled selectively and shifted various times during one trip.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Standard Harrier Shifting Tool

formatted-caption.caption-text: Standard Harrier Shifting Tool

linkTarget.anchoringText: Midale oil producers are normally cased-hole verticals or open-hole horizontals, which are completed commingled across the different horizons, as shown in Figure 17. Over time, producers significantly short circuit with the injectors and are shut in due to uneconomic high water cut (> 99.5%) and/or huge GOR (mainly CO2 gas), which leaves behind significant oil.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Cased-hole vertical oil producer selected for trial well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cased-hole vertical oil producer selected for trial well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 18 demonstrates potential shortcut pathways, via natural fractures, for the injected fluids (CO2 and/or Water), from a WAG injector towards a horizontal oil wellbore, and then towards the vertical oil producer via one of the present horizons with higher K*h (=perm × zone height). It is this vertical oil well that was selected for the ICD field trial.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Injection Pattern surrounding trial

formatted-caption.caption-text: Injection Pattern surrounding trial

linkTarget.anchoringText: This vertical trial well had previously produced 160 MBbl of Oil and 1.9 MMBbl of Water (averaged cumulative water cut: 95%). But it was declared uneconomic and shut-in in 2014 because of high water cut (> 99.5%) and elevated GOR (> 220,000 scf/Bbl, mainly CO2), as shown in Figure 19.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Production History of Trial Producer

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production History of Trial Producer

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 20 shows a good CBL (Slim Cement Mapping Tool or SCMT) for the selected trial well, which ensures the required hydraulic isolation behind casing. The wavy shape of the zebra pattern with the delay presented on the VDL and the low CBL amplitude across and above the perfs to the depth of 1400m infers reasonable isolation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Cement Bond (SCMT) Log on Trial Candidate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cement Bond (SCMT) Log on Trial Candidate

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 21 shows the results for the 3 zones of the trial well. The RST tool was run through tubing. The RST utilized sigma and carbon-oxygen measurement to process oil saturation because the play is under both water flood and CO2 gas injection, where hydrogen-based tools can’t be used. The RST C/O oil curve shows the presence of a pocket of oil (denoted by the green shaded horizontal parabola) across M2 and M3 formaiton.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: RST analysis behind casing

formatted-caption.caption-text: RST analysis behind casing

linkTarget.anchoringText: The trial well candidate was re-opened, tested and PLT’d in 2015 to establish a base-line for current conditions and for designing the ICD completion. The average ratios were: 0.4% oil cut (OC), 99.6% water cut (WC), 32,000 scf/bbl gas oil ratio (GOR), with rates up to 2,050 blpd, 10 bopd and 346 Mscfd, as shown in Table 2 and Figure 22. Moreover, the water cut and GOR performance versus fluid rate are shown in Figure 23 and Figure 24.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Well test data of trial candidate well before ICD installation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well test data of trial candidate well before ICD installation

linkTarget.anchoringText: The trial well candidate was re-opened, tested and PLT’d in 2015 to establish a base-line for current conditions and for designing the ICD completion. The average ratios were: 0.4% oil cut (OC), 99.6% water cut (WC), 32,000 scf/bbl gas oil ratio (GOR), with rates up to 2,050 blpd, 10 bopd and 346 Mscfd, as shown in Table 2 and Figure 22. Moreover, the water cut and GOR performance versus fluid rate are shown in Figure 23 and Figure 24.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Water cut and oil rate vs liquid rate for trial candidate well before ICDs

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water cut and oil rate vs liquid rate for trial candidate well before ICDs

linkTarget.anchoringText: The trial well candidate was re-opened, tested and PLT’d in 2015 to establish a base-line for current conditions and for designing the ICD completion. The average ratios were: 0.4% oil cut (OC), 99.6% water cut (WC), 32,000 scf/bbl gas oil ratio (GOR), with rates up to 2,050 blpd, 10 bopd and 346 Mscfd, as shown in Table 2 and Figure 22. Moreover, the water cut and GOR performance versus fluid rate are shown in Figure 23 and Figure 24.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: GOR and oil rate vs liquid rate for trial well before ICDs

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR and oil rate vs liquid rate for trial well before ICDs

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition, PLT was performed over three days in August 2015. Several passes were executed using Dual DEFT tool, followed by additional run with DEFT/GHOST PLT tools. This PLT (Figure 25) showed that the lowest horizon (M3) was highly swept by water (during which the WAG injector was injecting water); furthermore, it also revealed the best oil cut presence within the second horizon (M2), as summarized in Table 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: PLT profile of trial well before ICD installation

formatted-caption.caption-text: PLT profile of trial well before ICD installation

linkTarget.anchoringText: By varying the wellhead pressure (WHP), accurate Inflow Performance Relationship (IPR) curves were generated for the no-ICD case for each zone from predicted oil, water and gas rates for different wellhead pressures. The next step was to perform similar hydraulic simulations using packers to compartmentalize the three zones and using passive ICDs to separately control the inflow from each zone. Figure 26 shows the two modelling configurations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Wellbore Configuration for Modeling (No ICD, With ICD)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wellbore Configuration for Modeling (No ICD, With ICD)

linkTarget.anchoringText: It was decided to make the nozzle setting equal for each zone because for future wells’ PLT data will likely not be available to optimize the setting on each zone, because of expense. Figure 27 shows wellhead liquid rate versus wellhead pressure for different nozzle settings (i.e., cross section area of nozzle throat). Note how the curves fall off steeper for WHPs below 3500 psi indicating that not much is gained by lowering WHP below this value.

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: Predicted flow performance curves for

formatted-caption.caption-text: Predicted flow performance curves for

image-wrap.label: Figure 28
image-wrap.caption: Oil rate and WOR vs throat area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil rate and WOR vs throat area

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 29 shows the oil production rate versus throat area for each zone as well as well total. M2 has the lowest watercut which helps explain the highest oil production rate. Also shown (black curve) is the water-oil ratio which is minimized at 25.6 mm^2. Although minimizing water-oil ratio minimizes the cost of handling water production on surface, it is not necessarily the most economical setting since the oil rates are still rising sharply with increasing nozzle throat area.

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: Liquid rate and WC vs throat area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Liquid rate and WC vs throat area

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 30 shows wellhead pressure versus predicted liquid rate for 103.2 mm^2 nozzle throat area per zone. Ignoring zone M1, which produces much less liquid than zones M2 and M3, note that the passive ICD setting causes less liquid to produce from M3 because it’s choked back, but produces much more liquid from M2 because M3 is significantly choked back, thereby allowing M2 to produce more. The difference increases as WHP decreases.

image-wrap.label: Figure 30
image-wrap.caption: WHP vs liq rate per zone w/wo ICDs

formatted-caption.caption-text: WHP vs liq rate per zone w/wo ICDs

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 31 shows predicted wellhead pressure versus stock tank oil rate for 103.2 mm^2 nozzle throat area per zone. Note that the passive ICD setting causes less oil to produce from M3 because it’s significantly choked back, but produces much more oil from M2 because it’s less choked back. The difference increases as WHP decreases. Hence ICDs produce more oil by choking zones that have both high flow rate and high watercut.

image-wrap.label: Figure 31
image-wrap.caption: WHP vs oil rate for each zone w/wo ICD

formatted-caption.caption-text: WHP vs oil rate for each zone w/wo ICD

linkTarget.anchoringText: Note that both valves can be opened for each zone giving a third nozzle ICD setting. The three types of nozzles are shown in Figure 32. Note that the SFN nozzle is a standard flow nozzle (SFN), not a crossflow nozzle, because we could not get enough open flow area through the CFN to satisfy the test objectives.

image-wrap.label: Figure 32
image-wrap.caption: The 3 nozzle types used for the well test

formatted-caption.caption-text: The 3 nozzle types used for the well test

linkTarget.anchoringText: After the ICD design was completed, the trial well was recompleted by isolating the three producing zones with packers and installing the 2-valve, 3-position inflow subs containing the nozzles and AICVs, as shown in Figure 33.

image-wrap.label: Figure 33
image-wrap.caption: ICD completion: packers, 3ICI subs, AICVs & nozzles

formatted-caption.caption-text: ICD completion: packers, 3ICI subs, AICVs & nozzles

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 34 shows the completion diagram along with the GR and CBL logs. The plan was to test this well under various configurations or modes, such as: ICD (nozzles) mode, AICV(s) mode and combined ICD/ AICV mode. The performances of some of the modes tested to date are presented next.

image-wrap.label: Figure 34
image-wrap.caption: ICD completion showing logs and spacing

formatted-caption.caption-text: ICD completion showing logs and spacing

linkTarget.anchoringText: For this mode, the Inflow Subs were set at the first (PP1 see Table 4) nozzle settings for each of the three horizons: Marly 1 (M1), Marly 2 (M2) and Marly 3 (M3). Followed, the well was tested again. The results are shown in Figure 35. Note the significant increase in oil rate around Feb-24 when the liquid rate increased beyond 2000 BLPD. Above this rate, ICDs started choking unwanted inflow from M3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 35
image-wrap.caption: Well test data for PP1 nozzle mode in each zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well test data for PP1 nozzle mode in each zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: Under this configuration, significant improvements were noted, as summarized in Table 5. Moreover, water cut and GOR performance versus fluid rate are shown in Figure 36 and Figure 37.

image-wrap.label: Figure 36
image-wrap.caption: Watercut and oil rate vs liquid rate for PP1 nozzle mode per zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Watercut and oil rate vs liquid rate for PP1 nozzle mode per zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: Under this configuration, significant improvements were noted, as summarized in Table 5. Moreover, water cut and GOR performance versus fluid rate are shown in Figure 36 and Figure 37.

image-wrap.label: Figure 37
image-wrap.caption: GOR and Oil rate vs liquid rate for PP1 nozzle mode

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR and Oil rate vs liquid rate for PP1 nozzle mode

linkTarget.anchoringText: For this configuration and field test, the inflow subs were set at AICVs (2 AICVs open per zone) for two upper horizons (M1 & M2), while the third inflow sub for the deepest horizon (M3) was left on PP1 nozzles. Results are shown in Figure 38.

image-wrap.label: Figure 38
image-wrap.caption: Well testing data combined AICVs & ICDs (nozzles) mode

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well testing data combined AICVs & ICDs (nozzles) mode

linkTarget.anchoringText: Water cut performance versus fluid rate are shown in Figure 39.

image-wrap.label: Figure 39
image-wrap.caption: Combined AICVs & ICDs mode water cut and oil rate vs liquid rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Combined AICVs & ICDs mode water cut and oil rate vs liquid rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: The GOR performance is shown in Figure 40. Once again the GORs were reduced significantly – this time by the combination of ICDs and AICVs.

image-wrap.label: Figure 40
image-wrap.caption: Combined AICVs & ICDs mode GOR and oil rate vs liquid rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Combined AICVs & ICDs mode GOR and oil rate vs liquid rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: For this mode, the inflow subs were set at AICVs (2 AICVs open per zone) for each of the three horizons (M1, M2 and M3). The tests results are shown in Figure 41. Although operational problems were encountered that required a lengthy shutdown, improvements were again noted in the oil production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 41
image-wrap.caption: Well test data AICVs-only mode

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well test data AICVs-only mode

linkTarget.anchoringText: The date and time when this leak began and how it progressed is still unknown, although it is highly probabable that there was no leak prior to testing the second configuration presented above. The oil rate, watercut and GOR data versus liquid rate is provided in Figure 42 and Figure 43. The surprise increase in watercut above 2500 BLPD is likely due to the bypass leak. The lower GOR with AICVs is noted.

image-wrap.label: Figure 42
image-wrap.caption: AICVs-only mode water cut and oil rate vs liquid rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: AICVs-only mode water cut and oil rate vs liquid rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: The date and time when this leak began and how it progressed is still unknown, although it is highly probabable that there was no leak prior to testing the second configuration presented above. The oil rate, watercut and GOR data versus liquid rate is provided in Figure 42 and Figure 43. The surprise increase in watercut above 2500 BLPD is likely due to the bypass leak. The lower GOR with AICVs is noted.

image-wrap.label: Figure 43
image-wrap.caption: AICVs-only mode GOR and oil rate vs liquid rate
